channel.title: NYT > Health
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Four States Sue Administration Over Loss of Public Health Funds
item.description: The states, all led by Democrats, claim the cuts were intended as retribution and will harm efforts to control H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted infections.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. The agency administered block grants for H.I.V. prevention that were allocated to public health departments in California, Colorado, Illinois and Minnesota.

item.title: U.S. Health Officials Defend Rejection of Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.description: The F.D.A.’s refusal to examine the company’s mRNA shot drew widespread criticism from doctors and was divisive within the agency.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Marty Makary, the F.D.A. commissioner, suggested that the agency might eventually approve Moderna’s mRNA flu vaccine.

item.title: Dr. Oz Says Drinking Is a ‘Social Lubricant.’ Some Experts Worry About That.
item.description: “Most of the harm that comes from alcohol,” said one researcher, is “due mostly or mainly to drinking with their buddies.”
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Edu Bayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most research examining the effects of alcohol in a controlled laboratory setting has ignored the social context in which most drinking occurs.

item.title: Trump Administration to Cut $600 Million in Health Funding From Four States
item.description: The states, all led by Democrats, used the grants to support a wide variety of functions, including H.I.V. prevention and surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Cuts totaling about $600 million will affect funds to health departments and smaller partner organizations, including the Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago.

item.title: Mexico May Be on Brink of Losing Its Measles-Free Status
item.description: The country’s confirmed cases have topped 9,000 since last year, raising fears that a high-stakes evaluation in April could lead to its status being revoked.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: A health worker administering a dose of the measles vaccine in Mexico City last week. “We are confident that the outbreak will be controlled,” President Claudia Sheinbaum said on Wednesday.

item.title: How Are Health Care Costs Affecting You?
item.description: We want to hear from readers who are trying to manage their medical bills and their health insurance costs.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson

item.title: A.I. Is Making Doctors Answer a Question: What Are They Really Good For?
item.description: Many physicians find chatbots threatening, but that doesn’t mean they’re giving up on medicine.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: 2 to 3 Cups of Coffee a Day May Reduce Dementia Risk. But Not if It’s Decaf.
item.description: One to two cups of caffeinated tea per day helps too, researchers found after following nearly 132,000 people for 40 years.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.media:description: Beyond two and a half cups of coffee daily, the advantage plateaued, possibly because there’s a limit to how much caffeine our bodies can metabolize, researchers said.

item.title: Hims & Hers Withdraws Knockoff Weight-Loss Pill After Regulatory Scrutiny
item.description: Federal officials had warned that the new product from the online provider of weight loss drugs might be illegal.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins

item.title: Portland Lawsuit Alleges Tear Gas Use by ICE Is a Health Threat
item.description: A novel lawsuit in Portland argues the chemicals are a health threat that have soaked into apartment walls, furniture and even children’s toys.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: An October incident outside an ICE facility in Portland, Ore. Residents across the street have sued over the use of tear gas.

item.title: How Hate Groups Are Using Online Games to Recruit Kids
item.description: Fringe movements are using games and other online platforms to draw growing numbers of children to their causes, new data and dozens of interviews show.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.category: Global Project Against Hate and Extremism
item.media:description: Extremists are now using video games like Roblox to recruit new followers.

item.title: F.D.A. Refuses to Review Moderna Flu Vaccine
item.description: The vaccine maker’s shots involve the successful Covid vaccines’ RNA technology. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has broadly rejected it, canceling millions of dollars in research projects.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Moderna is a pioneer in using mRNA technology, first with the Covid vaccine. Its flu shot was being developed for people 50 and older.

item.title: 4 Dead in Mushroom Poisoning Outbreak in California
item.description: State health officials discouraged foraging this year, saying that toxic mushrooms can easily be confused with safe ones to eat.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: California Department of Public Health, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Complications from death cap mushroom poisoning can include liver and kidney failure and seizures.

item.title: Psychiatrist Says Kennedy Was ‘Not Accurate’ in Discussing His Keto Studies
item.description: Dr. Christopher M. Palmer said in an interview that the keto diet, while promising, did not “cure” schizophrenia as the health secretary had claimed.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Wednesday, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said that “we now know that the things that you eat are driving mental illness in this country,” and that a doctor at Harvard had “cured schizophrenia using keto diets.”

item.title: TrumpRx: What to Know About Insurance Benefits, Pricing and Savings
item.description: People may be able to pay less for prescriptions with their insurance rather than via the new government website. The Trump drugstore is meant to help people buy medications using their own money.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: President Trump; Dr. Mehmet Oz, who oversees Medicare and Medicaid; and Joe Gebbia, who oversees the design of government websites, unveiled TrumpRx at the Eisenhower Executive Office Building on Thursday.

item.title: A Super Bowl Message From MAHA and Mike Tyson: Processed Food Kills
item.description: A provocative new ad featuring the boxer makes the case for Americans to “eat real food.”
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:description: In a Super Bowl ad paid for by MAHA Center, the boxer Mike Tyson encourages healthy eating and criticizes obesity.

item.title: Federal Vaccine Advisers Take Aim at Covid Shots
item.description: One panelist accused the F.D.A. of withholding data on potential harms. The advisers also are reviewing research on vaccines given to pregnant women.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Dr. Robert Malone, during a December meeting of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices in Atlanta.

item.title: TrumpRx, the President’s Online Drugstore, Opens for Business
item.description: TrumpRx is aimed at helping patients use their own money to buy medicines. But researchers who study drug pricing warned that many patients could pay too much if they use the site.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:description: The TrumpRx website is meant to be an entry point for consumers to search for their medicines and then direct them to manufacturers’ websites to buy the drugs directly.

item.title: Nancy Guthrie Kidnapping Shows Limits of Tracking Pacemakers in Police Work
item.description: The heart devices do not track location, nor do they transmit across large distances.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: BSIP/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Most heart patients use remote monitoring, which means a pacemaker transmits its data to a nearby device.

item.title: Kennedy Makes Unfounded Claim That Keto Diet Can ‘Cure’ Schizophrenia
item.description: The claim vastly overstates preliminary research into whether the high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet might help people with the disorder, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in Nashville on Wednesday. Mr. Kennedy has a history of promoting ideas with little to no scientific evidence to back them up.

item.title: TrumpRx Is Set to Go Live on Thursday
item.description: The government website is meant to connect Americans with drug companies to buy prescriptions directly with their own money. It is not clear how many patients will save money.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: President Trump announced an effort to lower drug prices last year.

item.title: What Does It Mean to Be Touch-Starved?
item.description: Research says that our health can suffer when we don’t experience enough physical contact. Here’s how to get more.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: He Built a Server to Protect Indigenous Health Data
item.description: Joseph Yracheta was in charge of a repository that compiled and protected tribal health data. Then its funding was cut.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: Tara Weston for The New York Times

item.title: F.D.A. Relaxes Rules on ‘Naturally Derived’ Dyes
item.description: Food makers will now be able to claim that their products have “no artificial colors,” so long as they use dyes that are not petroleum-based.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: “We’re asking people now, ‘Eat real food,’” Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said at the Tennessee State Capitol on Wednesday.
